item.title: 155 – Not
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Not It’s the same as a trout leaping from the bathtub. The trout living in a room whose ceiling he is monarch under. A god of the fourth wall broken by the rainbow gleam of the trout who is a … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Not

It’s the same as a trout
leaping from the bathtub.
The trout living in a room
whose ceiling he is monarch under.
A god of the fourth wall broken
by the rainbow gleam of the trout
who is a beautiful question
arcing the white tiled space
of the bathroom. A moment
out of time. We start here
with a trout, leaping.
Where we go now
is impossible.

item.title: 154 – Moat
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Moat I’ve dug a tiny moat with just my hands right here: the Q in question: a curling stream the tail or stiffened arm of why of all of this. I stand or sit, little place to lean, a little … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Moat

I’ve dug a tiny moat
with just my hands
right here: the Q

in question: a curling stream
the tail or stiffened arm of
why of all of this.

I stand or sit, little place
to lean, a little prince
on a little island.

I plant a garden
with just my hands:
rushes, reeds, marsh grass

tend the greening oases.
Gnats cloud, merganser
peddle up stream.

Ibis cape and land, propped
one-legged, watching
heads-under-wing.

This weedy Eden sprouts
weedy questions shedding
a thousand more in the wind.

What answers
gurgle from the stream’s throat
full of smooth stones

clear water
carving Q
a deeper channel.

item.title: 153 – Almonds
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Almonds My latent racism tastes faintly of cyanide, tingling my tongue with a lazy epithet I hum off-hand & would never admit. It worms its way up from where my nightshade grows, blooming warm in strident certitude & quickly withering. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Almonds

My latent racism tastes faintly
of cyanide, tingling my tongue
with a lazy epithet I hum off-hand
& would never admit.

It worms its way up
from where my nightshade grows,
blooming warm in strident certitude
& quickly withering.

Papery skin inside my skin
catches in the back of my throat
as an almond might
choking, slowly poisoning.

If smell it on my breath
though I’ve said nothing outright
I’llÂ  deny deny deny
but for the grit in my teeth.

When I die I pray they find a stump
in me hacked and felled at the root, not
this vibrant tree shaking
bitter fruit.

item.title: 152 – Diamonds
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Diamonds Daughters dig the dirt for blessings hidden for you alone tucked up under green grass and daffodils, the shining gloss of pavement and caves deck-eaves make. Hunt worms and beetles. Turn every rock. The dirt under your nails is … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Diamonds

Daughters dig the dirt
for blessings hidden
for you alone

tucked up under green grass
and daffodils, the shining gloss of pavement
and caves deck-eaves make.

Hunt worms and beetles.
Turn every rock. The dirt under your nails
is gleaming glorious.

Bluebird cheers you on
from the apple tree you climb
to get a better vantage.

Ignore the undermining shouts of men
to climb down, clean up,
quit digging. Keep digging

diamonds hidden
where men can’t see.
Keep to the task

until the mine you rise from
is your own, dug wholly
by your hands

wiser now and worn
digging diamonds
only you could find.

item.title: 151 – A Little Drunk
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: A Little Drunk It’s late. I’m a little drunk and spooling out a poem at the eleventh hour. Tomorrow’s lark will come too early. The cat’s keening I’ll bat at absently. What rising will happen when we come to it. … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
A Little Drunk

It’s late. I’m a little drunk
and spooling out
a poem at the eleventh hour.
Tomorrow’s lark will come
too early. The cat’s keening
I’ll bat at absently. What rising
will happen when we come to it.
Now a brief unbuckling
of words, a waking dream
blurred a little longer.

(d)

item.title: 150 – Wings
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Wings I bump into Pete and lean awhile. The cafe’s nearly closed. The kids eat their wings, licking sticky fingers. Cannibal grins. Clouds are coming off the Cascades. Pete flexes gently, says his fingers tingle with the pressure change and … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Wings

I bump into Pete and lean awhile.
The cafe’s nearly closed. The kids eat
their wings, licking sticky fingers.
Cannibal grins. Clouds are coming
off the Cascades. Pete flexes gently,
says his fingers tingle with the pressure
change and every time he passes
the equipment shed. The machine
still whines when he powers it on,
jawing for the rest of him. We’ve all lost
something out here we’re trying to reattach:
the better part of years, family land, houses
and the things inside, knowing
just when our bodies will give and break.
Each hard-packed grave is a home we’ve built.
The kids are restless. We shake
gentle and shuffle off, me
to my corner to watch the storm spread.
The wings, extra hot, make me tear. I suck
each bone clean of meat and grease,
a charnel pile on the empty plate.
The celery sticks out, bright green
challenger as the wind and dust descend.

item.title: 149 – Honor Killing
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Honor Killing None give land for graves. The Ganges erases all shame but the bricks bearing her names, heals and hides tangled hair hands lifting in the current in prayer for the dead and the dying.
item.content:encoded:
Honor Killing

None give land
for graves.

The Ganges erases all
shame

but the bricks
bearing her names,

heals
and hides

tangled hair
hands lifting in the current

in prayer
for the dead

and the dying.

item.title: 148 – A Reading at First United Methodist
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: A Reading at First United Methodist The annex’s an ugly, open space curved like the hold of a ship crammed with old mustardy chairs. Home to church auctions and prayer breakfasts, the room fills with color from the stained glass … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
A Reading at First United Methodist

The annex’s an ugly, open space
curved like the hold of a ship
crammed with old mustardy chairs.
Home to church auctions and prayer
breakfasts, the room fills with color
from the stained glass of Christ
and the saints along the west wall.
Family and friends who’d never turn up
here, who’ll soon beÂ  an audience,
mingle, graze, drink orange bev
or coffee, dunking animal crackers
only to have the pink frosting skim off.
Patrick–who’s poem is on page 82,
who’ll read in a halting, salted voice
and stop the murmuring dead
like sight of land after months at sea–
laughs and laughs. We settle at a signal.
Introductions and thanks. Cell phones silenced.
Polite applause. And we shove off
into an uncertain sea of words
and the voices that make waves of them.
Patrick rises in a crest and descends
to his seat, followed by others alike
and unlike. We clap our thunder loud
for each. Pitch and yaw. Roll and holler.
Held hostage, shanghaied
away from ghost linoleum and fading hymnals
we are willing deckhands, word-pirates
for a night, leaving the safety of land to sail
out into the deepest ocean.

item.title: 147 – Genuflection
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Genuflection it’s a habit not that I call it that I won’t call it that if you ask –don’t– say issue concern off-night nerves never habit: a thing incarnated in adoration never add -iction too close to the scripted lie … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Genuflection

it’s a habit
not that
I call it that

I won’t call it that
if you ask

–don’t–

say issue concern
off-night nerves never

habit: a thing incarnated
in adoration

never add
-iction too close

to the scripted
lie winkÂ Â Â  pious toss of the head

de-
genuflect-
ion

belly up unto the altar
& taste

the proffered cup

item.title: 146 – Memorial Day
item.dc:creator: Graham
item.description: Memorial Day Remember, please: we wave many flags woven from many fabrics. Not every with stripe or star. Not each planted on the moon. We raise our own tattered glory on a bent pole not in solemn salute commanding respect … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Memorial Day

Remember, please: we wave
many flags woven
from many fabrics.

Not every with stripe
or star. Not each planted
on the moon.

We raise our own
tattered glory
on a bent pole

not in solemn salute
commanding
respect or sorrow

but a tender hand
at sunset
shading the eye

to see
what each of us
lets fly free.
